Mexico-based Plata receives final approval for a banking license, leapfrogging peers including Nubank and Mercado Pago that are still in the process of getting the coveted authorization https://t.co/X40He5EPHT

üö® ùòΩùôçùôÄùòºùôÜùôÑùôâùôÇ:¬†üá≤üáΩ Mexico-based Plata Card has received its full banking license, leapfrogging heavyweights like Nubank and¬†Mercado Pago, which are still waiting for final approval.

After a three-year regulatory process, Plata is now officially a bank!

That‚Äôs a big deal.

Until now, Plata only offered credit cards. With a banking license, it can expand into deposits, lending, and broader financial services ‚Äî unlocking deeper relationships with Mexico‚Äôs large underbanked population.

A few key data points:

‚Ä¢ Valuation: $3.1 billion
‚Ä¢ 3 million active users
‚Ä¢ 3 years to secure the license

Meanwhile:

‚Ä¢ Revolut is also building its banking presence in Mexico
‚Ä¢ Klar acquired Banorte‚Äôs digital unit Bineo to fast-track a license
‚Ä¢¬†MercadoLibre¬†and Nubank are still in process

Mexico is becoming one of the most strategic battlegrounds in global FinTech:

üëâ Large underbanked population
üëâ Growing middle class
üëâ Strong digital adoption
üëâ Regulators willing, but cautious

The key shift?

FinTechs are no longer satisfied with wallets and cards.

They want full banking stacks.

And in Mexico, the license is the real moat.

Who wins this race: local champions like Plata, regional giants like Nubank, or global players like Revolut?

What do you think?
